item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Hezbollah Says a Commander Was Killed in a Strike in Lebanon
item.description: A Lebanese security official said the commander was part of Hezbollah’s Radwan unit, which Israel says aims to infiltrate its northern border.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times

item.title: Exhausted, on the Defensive and at ‘Hell’s Gate’ in Ukraine
item.description: The country’s forces along a broad stretch of the front say that, with Russia pushing forward, the war has never been so dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Vladyslav Golovin and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Two Capitol Riots. Two Very Different Results.
item.description: Why has Brazil united in rejecting last year’s insurrection, while the United States remains deeply divided over Jan. 6?
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Eraldo Peres/Associated Press, Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Jan. 8 of last year, a mob ransacked Brazil’s Congress and other offices, claiming an election had been stolen. Unlike the Jan. 6 rioters in Washington, the Brazilian protesters have almost no support now.

item.title: Pope Francis Calls For Global Ban on Surrogacy
item.description: The pope said that an unborn child must not be “turned into an object of trafficking,” expanding his condemnation of a practice already illegal in Italy and some other European countries.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis, pictured at the Vatican last summer, included surrogacy among wars, terrorism and other practices he considers threats to peace.

item.title: French Prime Minister, Élisabeth Borne, Resigns
item.description: Élisabeth Borne, only the second woman to occupy the position, stepped down as President Emmanuel Macron tries to inject fresh energy into his second term.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne in her office in Paris in 2022.

item.title: India and Maldives Trade Barbs After Modi’s Beach Visit
item.description: Some in the Maldives were critical of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s trip to nearby Indian islands to promote tourism, seeing it as an attempt to draw visitors away from their nation.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:description: The Maldives in December. The uproar over where Indians take their beach vacations frames a broader contest with China.

item.title: Former Gambian Politician on Trial for Murder in Milestone Swiss Case
item.description: Ousman Sonko served the authoritarian president of Gambia for years, seeking asylum in Switzerland after losing his job. Now he faces charges of crimes against humanity.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Elodie Le Maou/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Swiss Federal Criminal Court at the opening day of the trial of Ousman Sonko in Bellinzona, southern Switzerland on Monday.

item.title: Pakistani Justices Reject Ban for Politicians With Past Convictions
item.description: The decision by the Supreme Court paves the way for a former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, to run in parliamentary elections in February.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Nawaz Sharif, former prime minister of Pakistan, addressing his supporters during a rally in Lahore in October.

item.title: China Says It Detained a Foreign Consultant for Spying for Britain
item.description: The Ministry of State Security says the consultant collected intelligence and found people on behalf of MI6, Britain’s spy agency.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:description: A Chinese paramilitary police officer stands guard outside the British Embassy in Beijing.

item.title: India’s Top Court Reverses Early Release of 11 Men Convicted of Gang Rape
item.description: The case of Bilkis Bano, who was three months pregnant when she was attacked, became a powerful symbol of communal bloodshed and of the widespread violence against women in the country.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A rally in 2022 in Kolkata, India, in support of Bilkis Bano, who was raped in 2002.

item.title: Russian Missiles Pound Ukraine, Officials Say
item.description: The attack killed at least four people, wounded many others and caused heavy damage. It came as Moscow has intensified air assaults in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Taking shelter inside a subway station in Kyiv, Ukraine, during an air raid alert on Monday.

item.title: Writing in an Endangered Language to Honor, and Challenge, Traditions
item.description: In “How to Be a Good Savage,” Mikeas Sánchez’ poems help preserve her language, Zoque, and allow it to commingle with English and Spanish, in an effort that is both global and deeply local.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin P. Russell
item.category: How to Be a Good Savage and Other Poems (Book)
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zoque is spoken by about 100,000 people, but Mikeas Sánchez speaks an endangered variant. Zoque also has little surviving written tradition.

item.title: A Small-Town Stabbing Takes On a Larger Significance for France
item.description: The death might have been just a local tragedy. But some of the suspects were from an immigrant community, turning the case into a cause célèbre for the far right.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Banners in Romans-sur-Isère’s immigrant neighborhood of La Monnaie, denouncing racism and calling for justice for all.

item.title: Blessing of Same-Sex Couples Rankles Africa’s Catholics
item.description: It is out of step with the continent’s values, many bishops say, and threatens to derail expansion in the church’s fastest growing region in the world.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Worshipers of the Legio Maria of African Church Mission gathering for the Christmas Eve Mass in December at a church near Ugunja, Kenya.

item.title: Oct. 7 Assaults, Including Sexual Violence, Could Be Crimes Against Humanity, U.N. Experts Say
item.description: The experts’ statement came after the United Nations had been the focus of months of frustrated accusations that it was ignoring the rape and mutilation of women during the Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The former Meta executive Sheryl Sandberg, at U.N. headquarters in New York in early December, speaking at a presentation on sexual violence during the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Lebanon Kill Hezbollah Commander, Militia Says
item.description: The latest strikes across Israel’s northern border came as the U.S. secretary of state made another trip to the Middle East in efforts to prevent a wider war.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Isabel Kershner and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Hezbollah Military Media Office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by the Hezbollah military’s press office showing Wissam Hassan al-Tawil, the Hezbollah commander killed in an Israeli strike in Lebanon on Monday.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Radwan Unit Lost a Commander in a Strike. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The elite unit of the Lebanese armed group lost a commander in a strike on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Israeli military analysts say the mission of Hezbollah’s Radwan force is to conquer the northern Israeli region of Galilee.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s New Phase in Gaza
item.description: Also, a recap of the Golden Globes.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier operating during an escorted tour by the military for international journalists in the central Gaza Strip on Monday.

item.title: United and Alaska Airlines Find Loose Parts on Boeing 737 Max 9 Jets
item.description: The announcements added to safety concerns about the Max 9. United said loose bolts were found on panels like the one that blew out during an Alaska Airlines flight.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Mark Walker
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Orange steps on Monday led up to the hole where a part of an Alaska Airlines plane blew out, forcing an emergency landing at Portland International Airport last week.

item.title: Franz Beckenbauer, ‘Der Kaiser’ of World Soccer, Dies at 78
item.description: In West Germany, he revolutionized his central defense position and was one of only three people to win the World Cup as a player and a coach.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Andrew Das
item.media:description: Franz Beckenbauer, second from right, led West Germany to a World Cup championship as a player in 1974.

item.title: Aharon Barak Is Israel’s Choice of Judge for Genocide Case in U.N. Court
item.description: Aharon Barak, a retired Israeli Supreme Court president, fought the government’s judicial overhaul plan. But it chose him for the panel hearing a case against it in a United Nations court.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aharon Barak, former president of Israel’s Supreme Court, in Tel Aviv last year.

item.title: ‘Welsh Tidy Mouse’ Tidies Tiny Welsh House
item.description: For months, a mysterious helper was cleaning up the work bench in Rodney Holbrook’s shed every night. He caught the visitor, tail and all, on video.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Israel Says It Is Shifting to a More Targeted Stage in Gaza War
item.description: Israeli officials privately say that they hope to complete the transition by the end of January, but that the timeline could change.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Adam Entous and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli official said the country would continue to reduce the number of troops in Gaza, a process that began this month.

item.title: Blinken Discusses Gaza Aid on Visit to Middle East
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state, on a trip to the Middle East that included a meeting with the Saudi crown prince, said such a move would require an end to fighting in Gaza and steps toward a Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, leaving Abu Dhabi on Monday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: A newly aggressive Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: An Iranian flag at Bushehr nuclear power plant. “We are back to square one,” a French diplomat said of efforts to curb Tehran’s nuclear program.

item.title: West Bank Violence Rises as Israel Vows to Wipe Out Hamas in Gaza
item.description: Diplomats toured the Mideast Sunday on a mission to stop the war from widening, but tensions in the Gaza Strip spread across the region.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Edward Wong and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: A funeral for Palestinians killed on Sunday in Jenin, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

item.title: From Lebanon to the Red Sea, a Broader Conflict With Iran Looms
item.description: With its proxies attacking from many vantage points and its nuclear program suddenly revived, Iran is posing a new challenge to the West — this time with Russia and China on its side.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: An Iranian flag at Bushehr nuclear power plant. “We are back to square one,” a French diplomat said of efforts to curb Tehran’s nuclear program.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Bangladesh’s Troubled Election
item.description: Plus why the first galaxies were banana-shaped.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Polling agents helping voters yesterday in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: London Tube Strike Called Off
item.description: London’s mayor announced late Sunday afternoon that a strike that would have crippled the city’s transit system this week had been suspended.
item.dc:creator: Erin McCann
item.media:description: Piccadilly Circus, in central London, last month.

item.title: Two Journalists Are Killed in Gaza, Including the Son of Al Jazeera Reporter
item.description: Hamza al-Dahdouh, the son of Al Jazeera’s Gaza bureau chief, and a second reporter were killed in what officials in the territory said was an Israeli airstrike. Two others were wounded.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: Wael al-Dahdouh, an Al Jazeera correspondent, holding the hand of his deceased son Hamza during his funeral in Rafah, Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Steel Acquisition Proposal Tests Biden’s Industrial Policy
item.description: The president is under pressure from Democrats and Republicans to block the sale to Japan’s Nippon Steel, which could upset a key foreign ally.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:description: U.S. Steel announced plans to be acquired by a Japanese competitor, Nippon Steel, in a $14.1 billion takeover bid.

item.title: ‘Two Men Down’: For Ukrainian Medics, It Was Time to Move
item.description: They are the first line of treatment for soldiers wounded on the battlefield, racing against time to try to save lives.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Injured Ukrainian soldiers, after arriving from the front line in an armored vehicle with combat medics, are stabilized before further transport to area hospitals. Combat medics with the 63rd Brigade of Armed Forces of Ukraine at a position in the Kreminna Forest, where they evacuate wounded soldiers and collect dead from the front trenches. Once stabilized, they're transported to a hospital for further care. Nicknamed the "black forest," fighting has been intense in this frontline region, near Lyman in the Donetsk Region, with Russian positions a close distance away.

item.title: War Brings Tensions, and Assault Rifles, Into an Israeli College
item.description: At the University of Haifa, more than 40 percent of students are Arab, some with family in Gaza, and many others have now been called up as soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yitzhak Cohen, 28, a law student and reservist, attending an orientation day in late December at the University of Haifa.

item.title: Bangladesh Leader Headed to 4th Straight Term in Vote Marred by Crackdown
item.description: With the opposition in jail or off the ballots in a boycott, the prime minister for the past 15 years was expected to maintain her grip on power in what appeared to be a low-turnout vote.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A polling station on Sunday in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: Dignified burials have become another casualty in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman and her daughters search a cemetery for the graves of relatives during a temporary cease-fire in November in central Gaza.

item.title: Blinken Continues His Middle East Tour in Hopes of Reducing Tensions
item.description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met separately in Amman with King Abdullah II and Ayman Safadi, Jordan’s foreign minister.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and the Jordanian foreign minister, Ayman Safadi, in Amman, Jordan, on Sunday.

item.title: Japan Earthquake Survivor in Her 90s Rescued After Five Days
item.description: The survivor, who was in her 90s, was dug out from under a collapsed house, injured but responsive.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Miharu Nishiyama
item.media:description: Destroyed houses after an earthquake in Suzu, Japan, on Sunday.

item.title: Arno J. Mayer, Unorthodox Historian of Europe’s Crises, Dies at 97
item.description: A Jewish refugee from the Nazis, he argued that World War I, World War II and the Holocaust were all part of a “second Thirty Years’ War.”
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: The historian Arno J. Mayer in 2013. He argued that both world wars and the Holocaust were the result of modern, liberal capitalism colliding with an entrenched European elite.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russian Attacks Kill 11 Civilians
item.description: Ukrainian officials said missile assaults had struck private houses, trapping residents under the rubble, and that the dead included five children.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: State Emergency Service of Ukraine, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo provided by the Ukrainian government showing rescue workers in Pokrovsk, in the Donetsk region, on Saturday.

item.title: Boeing’s 737 Max 9 and the Alaska Airline Grounding: What to Know
item.description: Boeing faced new safety questions after an Alaska Airlines jet made an emergency landing when a hole opened in its fuselage in midair.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze, Keith Bradsher and Melissa Eddy
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: An Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 aircraft in Seattle in 2021.

item.title: After Niger Coup, U.S. Scrambles to Keep a Vital Air Base
item.description: After the generals took charge, the United States was forced to suspend operations at its most strategic military asset in sub-Saharan Africa. Restarting them won’t be easy.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Eric Schmitt and Carmen Abd Ali
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Air Base 201 in Agadez, Niger, a vital military asset and the biggest construction job Air Force engineers ever undertook alone, has been mostly idle since the country’s coup in July.

item.title: Hezbollah Fires Rockets at Israel in Response to Killing in Beirut
item.description: Israel said it had fired back at militants involved in the rocket launches, but the exchange stopped short of a major escalation.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Smoke rising above Khiam, in southern Lebanon, after an Israeli bombardment on Saturday.

item.title: Resolving New Year’s Resolutions
item.description: What does it take to finally make a resolution stick?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s Foreign Student Surge Prompts Changes, and Anxiety
item.description: As international students flock to Canada, the country is looking closer at ways to protect them against labor and financial exploitation.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students after taking a shuttle bus from downtown Timmins, Ontario, to the local Northern College campus. The institution has seen a significant uptick in foreign students in recent years, mostly from India, as domestic enrollment has waned.

item.title: Ukraine’s Patriot Defenses at Work: Shuddering Booms and Bursts of Light
item.description: The American-provided air-defense systems have helped Ukraine defend itself against Russian assaults, but Washington has warned that it will not be able to keep them supplied for much longer.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Damage in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, in December after Russia targeted it with a salvo of missiles.

item.title: Quebec Still Longs for Its Lost Hockey Team, a Nationalist Symbol
item.description: Ever since the Quebec Nordiques decamped in 1995, leaving a hole in the Francophone city, vote-seeking officials have vowed to bring them back. But younger voters may be starting to forget the team.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A junior hockey league team, the Quebec Remparts, in red, competing in an arena that was built for 370 million Canadian dollars, in the hopes of attracting an N.H.L. team.

item.title: As Gaza Losses Mount Under Israeli Strikes, Proper Burials Are Another Casualty
item.description: “The lucky are those who have someone to bury them when they die,” Dr. Mohammad Abu Moussa, a radiologist at one Gaza hospital, said of those killed by Israeli airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Samar Abu Elouf and Yousef Masoud
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman and her daughters searching a cemetery for the graves of relatives during a truce in November in central Gaza.

item.title: In Indonesia, Democracy or Dynasty?
item.description: Critics say that hard-won progress toward democracy in Indonesia has been backsliding under Joko Widodo, a two-term president who was once a political outsider.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Gibran Rakabuming Raka, left, the elder son of President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, and Prabowo Subianto, the defense minister, greeting supporters in Jakarta in October.

item.title: Israeli Minister Proposes Plan for Postwar Gaza Amid Divisions
item.description: The plan exposed divisions in Israel’s war cabinet as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken returned to the Middle East on Friday in an effort to ease escalating tensions.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin, Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: Smoke billowing over Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, during an Israeli bombardment on Friday.

item.title: Galaxies in the Early Universe Were Shaped Like Bananas, Study Suggests
item.description: Images from the Webb telescope suggest that newborn galaxies look weirder than expected. Exactly how screwy was physics at the dawn of time?
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Terrorism in Iran Exposes a Vulnerability It Doesn’t Want to Admit
item.description: Even after the Islamic State took responsibility for deadly bombings, Iran’s government, facing public anger, blamed Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of a victim of Wednesday’s terrorist bombing in Kerman, on Friday in Tehran.

item.title: If You Wanna Mail My Letter, You Gotta Get Some Spice Girls Stamps
item.description: Royal Mail said on Friday that it was issuing a set of 15 stamps to celebrate the girl group’s 30th anniversary. The stamps will go on sale on Jan. 11.
item.dc:creator: Lola Fadulu
item.media:description: Royal Mail is issuing a set of 15 stamps to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Spice Girls.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Leader Says It Would Not Negotiate Peace With Israel Until War in Gaza Ends
item.description: In a televised speech, Hassan Nasrallah addressed Israeli citizens directly, warning that they “will be the first to pay the price” unless the military action stops.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A televised speech by Hassan Nasrallah, the head of Hezbollah, shown to Hezbollah supporters in Baalbek, Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: Playing for Time, U.K. Leader Sets Up Chance of U.S. Election Overlap
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak signaled that voters will go to the polls in the fall, around the time that the United States will be in the midst of its own pivotal vote.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain in Mansfield, England, on Thursday, where he said: “My working assumption is we’ll have a general election in the second half of this year.”

item.title: Neo-Nazi Podcasters Who Called for Prince Harry’s Death Are Sentenced
item.description: The men, who were described by the police as “homophobic, racist, antisemitic, Islamophobic and misogynistic,” received eight- and seven-year sentences.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Christopher Gibbons, left, and Tyrone Patten-Walsh.

item.title: Out of Sight, Out of Mind No More
item.description: The Africa Cup of Nations and the Asian Cup, once seen as poorly timed intrusions by European soccer, may finally be getting the respect they deserve.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Mohamed Salah, off to Africa for a month.

item.title: Families of American Hostages Held in Gaza Release ‘Bring Them Home’ TV Ad
item.description: The 30-second spot is set to air on cable channels and during Sunday network news programs in the United States for the next several weeks.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear

item.title: Blinken Returns to Middle East as Tensions Grow With Israel
item.description: Details of a clash between the U.S. secretary of state and Israel’s prime minister point to the challenges ahead.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the secretary of state, plans to visit Israel and the West Bank headquarters of the Palestinian Authority during a visit to the Middle East.

item.title: Putin Aims to Strengthen Russia’s Military by Easing Citizenship for Foreigners
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin is seeking to strengthen his military to fight in Ukraine while avoiding a potentially unpopular mobilization of Russians.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Russian recruits at a train station in Prudboi in September 2022. Russia imposed a draft of up to 300,000 reservists that month.
